column4: can anyone recommend a reference book that covers most topics on linux but isnt too technical... just something to help a beginner get out of trouble if they need it

I find Oreilly books to be good, but better if you already have an idea what you're doing.  I was thinking "Running Linux" as it was my first book, but thought the dummy book for RH7.3 was better for a newb
haha i have not a clue what im doing.. i just migrated to ubuntu yesterday after a lifetime on windows
Well, you're most of the way there then.  What in particular are you looking for?
just want to understand what the commands are that im typing in... i know i can just do them but i feel better if i have a small understanding of them
Have you discovered the man pages yet?  Not always very helpful, but sometimes they're a start
well the tutorials on how to get certain things working.. i just type in the code they give me without second thought of what its doing
yeah just reading some articles on the ubuntu website.. interesting stuff
and gizzo  thank you guys... i think i should be able to handle myself from here.. just a matter of taking my time and reading everything step by step i think
I have a book that gives pretty detailed descritions of commands, but it's a big 'un.
whats the name? ill see if amazon has it
had to get the borders sticker off.  ISBN# 0-13-147823-0   try that
let me know what you found
is it called, A Practical Guide to Linux(R) Commands, Editors, and Shell Programming?
